summary: This 1956 High Court of the Protectorate of the Gambia case involved a claim for recovery of possession of land formerly owned by Ousman N'Jie Modji, who died intestate. The plaintiffs included his widow and three daughters, while the first defendant was his ward, Samba N'Jie, who had occupied the land since 1941 under a tenancy-at-will. The court held that under native law and custom, the widow had no proprietary interest in the land, which passed to the children. The claim against the first defendant was time-barred under the Limitation Acts of 1833 and 1874 due to twelve years of uninterrupted possession. However, the claims succeeded against the other defendants—grantees of the first defendant—because their tenancies-at-will had not run the requisite twelve-year limitation period. The res judicata defence failed because prior native tribunal proceedings involved only the widow, not the daughters, who claimed independently.
verdict: The claim by the widow was dismissed; the claims by the daughters succeeded against the second, third, and fourth defendants but failed against the first defendant.
winningSide: Defendants (partially), with Samba N'Jie prevailing on limitation grounds, but losing as to portions granted to others.

jurisdiction.court: High Court of the Protectorate of the Gambia

rationaleHighlights: Under native law, land of an intestate passes to children, excluding the widow.
A tenancy-at-will triggers the 12-year limitation period from one year after commencement.
Samba N'Jie acquired possessory title over the portion he occupied due to long possession.
Grantees of a tenant-at-will do not acquire enforceable interests against the true owner.
The res judicata defence failed because the daughters were not parties or privies in the prior action.
The native tribunal’s decision was reversed on revision, but did not bind non-parties.
The daughters succeeded in recovering land from grantees whose possession was less than 12 years.
The widow lacked standing to claim as she held no interest under customary law.
